standfirst: Rescuers continue to look for survivors and pull bodies out of the rubble after an 11-storey building collapsed on Saturday near Chennai, southern India. The tower was still being built and fell after workers went inside to shelter from the rain during monsoon season. Building collapses are common in India due to lax regulations and substandard construction

standfirst: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un inspects submarine No 748 at an undisclosed location. Pictures from the country's official Korean Central News Agency (KCNA)

standfirst: A former lumberjack has used his jackhammer to fell a water tower in the Belarusian town of Zaslawye, with the dramatic demolition caught on video. Viktor Gordievitch says his method cost half of the quote for a traditional  explosive demolition – and insists it is safe, as long as you run quickly

standfirst: Stuntman Nick Macomber jumps off the 45th floor rooftop of the Four Seasons Hotel in Denver, Colorado on Thursday, with the help of a hydrogen and nitrogen-powered jetpack.  Macomber hovers and flies for about 30 seconds before landing back on the roof. The stunt was a test flight for a world record attempt scheduled for later this year, when Macomber will fly from the tallest structure in the southern hemisphere

standfirst: Sunday's poll pits a reforming president against a resurgent far right – and the stakes are high in a country weary of cocaine wars and paramilitaries. Now Mauricio Rodriguez, a special adviser to President Santos, warns that defeat will undo four years of progress
headline: A last plea as Colombia votes: 'Don't throw away the chance of peace'

standfirst: Spiders that can capture and eat fish have been discovered by scientists at the fringes of shallow fresh water. The study by a Swiss-Australian team appeared in the academic journal Plos One. It revealed that the amphibious creatures, more commonly found in warmer areas, can often swim and walk on the water's surface and are able to kill fish bigger and more powerful than themselves
headline: Fish-eating spiders discovered by scientists – video

standfirst: South African athlete Oscar Pistorius was not mentally ill when he shot girlfriend Reeva Steenkamp, a panel of experts conclude. The sportsman is surrounded by press as he arrives at Pretoria high court for his trial, which has resumed after a one-month break. Chief prosecutor Gerrie Nel refers to key parts of the conclusions in court, noting that the experts believe Pistorius was capable of appreciating the wrongfulness of his deed when he killed Steenkamp

standfirst: Security footage shows a lift malfunction in a skyscraper in Santiago, Chile, sending a man hurtling up 30 storeys in 15 seconds. Jose Vergara suffered serious injuries to his head and legs as the lift crashed into the ceiling of his apartment building. Vergara can be seen pressing buttons to try to stop the lift but only manages to open the doors

standfirst: A boat carrying 97 Indonesian migrants sank off the western coast of Malaysia on Wednesday. At least three people have died and another 34 people are missing. Malaysian officials say they believe the boat sank because it was overloaded

standfirst: At least 10 people injured after bull is let loose at a celebration in a Peruvian village. A bullfight had been held to mark the end of an annual festival and the bull was untied by the ring assistant, causing it to charge at the crowd. standfirst: Rainbow-clad members of the LGBT community gather in Mexico City at the capital's annual gay pride parade on Saturday. standfirst: Sydney surfers have a close encounter with a whale. A helicopter's camera caught the footage, which shows a surfer quickly swimming away as the whale flicks its tail. standfirst: Turkish police use teargas in central Istanbul to disperse protesters on Saturday, seeking to mark the one-year anniversary of mass anti-government demonstrations. standfirst:
Dangerous Acts follows a group of actors from Belarus who defied dictator Alexander Lukashenko by setting up an underground company tackling taboo subjects such as sexual orientation, alcoholism, suicide and politics. Their small theatre space in Minsk is in constant danger of being raided by police and many actors are now in exile, where they tour to great acclaim. Film-maker Madeleine Sackler used secret film smuggled out of Belarus to make her film.

Belarus Free Theatre's later work, Red Forest, opens at the Young Vic in London on 12 June.
Find out more about the film and the group

Win tickets to see Red Forest at the Young Vic with the Guardian's New East network
headline: Dangerous Acts: Belarus Free Theatre battles the KGB, dictatorship and exile - video

standfirst: After four days of fighting, the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (Isis) have seized Iraq's second biggest city, Mosul, and Tikrit, home town of former dictator Saddam Hussein, as well as other towns and cities north of Baghdad. They have continued their quick advance on Thursday, moving into towns just an hour's drive from the capital
headline: Iraq crisis: Isis marches on towards Baghdad as US weighs support - video report

standfirst: Footage of young children carrying rifles with Isis fighters has sparked concerns the militant Islamist group is recruiting young people. The video shows two boys brandishing the guns as part of a convoy in which Isis paraded weapons and vehicles seized from the Iraqi army in Mosul. Human rights groups say the rebels have recruited children as young as 14 in the past
headline: Iraq: gun-toting children paraded in Isis convoy - video

standfirst: More than 1,000 recruits from Karbala, a majority Shia province of southern Iraq, set off on Friday to reinforce government forces in their fight against advancing militants of the  Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (Isis). Isis gained more ground overnight, moving into two towns in the eastern province of Diyala
headline: Iraq: recruits from Karbala set off to help fight Isis – video

standfirst: US president Barack Obama is ruling out sending combat troops back into Iraq to quell the rise of the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (Isil). The Obama administration is pondering both military and diplomatic efforts to halt the jihadist army's advance through northern Iraq. Obama says the crisis is a "wake up call" for Iraqi troops, and implored them to do everything to defend their cities
headline: Barack Obama: I will not send US troops into Iraq to fight Isis - video

standfirst: President Barack Obama says the US will send up to 300 military advisers to support Iraqi forces confronting the radical Sunni militants Isis. standfirst: Isis militants declare an Islamic state, or 'caliphate' in an area straddling the border between Iraq and Syria. standfirst: Isis, the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, is a militant group so hardline that it was disavowed by al-Qaida. Recent photos and video appear to show members executing prisoners near Tikrit. Three years of civil war in Syria – and a manifesto that disavows notions of statehood and national boundaries – have helped it to claim hundreds of square miles of territory, and now it is gaining a foothold in Iraq, explains the Guardian's assistant foreign editor, Phoebe Greenwood
headline: What is Isis and what are its aims? – video
